message_text: After searching for scholarly articles that explore community, the results produced numerous papers and books that examine community around one's identity and personal needs.Merriam-Webster defines community as "a unified body of individuals."I would define community as a group of people that share a mutual identity, whether it be race, gender, religion, or sexual orientation. Furthermore, I believe a community is comprised of people who strongly associate themselves with that group.For me, an "online community" is one where the definitions above are present but, perhaps even more important, people are able to develop a true social presence. In other words, members of the group must be able to develop and convey a true sense of themselves that includes their personality, passions, interests, and emotions. In order to do this, members must engage clearly and frequently, as well as communicate effectively. I really like the book's definition of online communities as a virtual space where people "come together in meaningful ways" and with a sense of "purpose." Additionally, it is important for whichever platform is being utilized to have a clear structure. This is my vision of a successful online community. It's when people bring all parts of themselves to an online space, using a variety of technology, and are able to use the structure of the virtual space to help other members gain a perspective (and hopefully an accurate one) of who they are. Community members learn about one another, develop common interests, and eventually trust each other enough to rely on members and look to each other to learn more about others and themselves. With our culture being heavily dependent on body language to help us decipher messages and a need for face-to-face interactions, I believe developing a strong, viable online community poses great difficulty. I come from a background where online communities feel a little unnatural, so I am very excited to stretch myself outside of my comfort zone and I look forward to developing peer relationships in a virtual space. After reading the first chapter of "Building online learning communities" and searching for some articles and Wikipedia information, I have had an initial conception of "online learning community". In my opinion, two kinds of actors- facilitator and learner are fundamental factors in online learning community. Various online activities performed by these two kinds of actors comprise a online social context. This constructivist context is called online learning community. More importantly, only this constructivist context can be considered as "online learning community". Communities which are used as a platform to deliver teaching materials by instructors are not "online learning community".In order to form a social constructivist context, facilitator should clarify course goals, objectives, expected outcomes, guidelines, collaborative assignments to learners. During the learning process, the learner who is open-minded sharing, self-motivated and self-disciplined are more likely to be a successful online learner. Online activities (performed by both learners and facilitator) include social presence, collaborative activities, interactions and communications, reflective and transformative learning, etc. Details of these concepts please watch my Prezi shown below.My Prezi: What's online learning community?I believe community is important in online learning spaces. Because I believe learning is a social process. Online community is the space people share their thoughts, ideas, reflections, skills, technologies and make communications and interactions with others. When I think about defining online community, I think about how I as a program evaluator would think about it as an intervention in learning and what that may "look like". I reviewed a few published studies that evaluated different online communities (learning and professional). _The online communities that "succeeded" by some measure included these aspects: high engagement (measured by frequency of participation, depth of participation, or particular participation patterns), shared sense of vision (in most cases this was centered on a particular aspect of learning), _and sense of belonging or community loyalty (self report paired with measures of participation). The studies also discussed motivations such as relevance of knowledge sharing in community and perceived advantage of belonging and participating. The studies also either measured or discussed the role of self efficacy in fostering engagement. Participants needed to be confident enough in their own ability to share knowledge to be engaged.In a learning community it seems like it would be important to figure out what strengths different members bring to the table, scaffold discussions so that varied expertise is valued, and establish the trust among members early and consistently. I liked the "Building Online Learning Communities' reference to conscious community - the need for personal growth and transformation as part of that definition.The other piece that seemed missing from the studies I found was thinking about the role of discourse in building knowledge or learning in the community. It was perhaps implicit in the different measures of weblogs aItics from these studies but that seems to miss the constructivist thinking that R described in Prezi.Thinking about the definition makes me realize the challenges of thinking about evaluation with respect to online communities.

I firmly believe that community is important in online learning spaces because without a doubt it builds collaboration. Community in an online learning space allows members to create a sense of ownership and connection to others. In the paper, Building a Dynamic Online Learning Community among Adult Learners, it notes evidence of an online community forming from three markers: active participation, the forming of a shared identity, and the establishment of a social network. Without participation, you lack interaction, and therefore lack any opportunities to learn from each other (such through constructivism or active learning [noted in our book]). Our book really sums it up well in the first chapter, "The development of community as part of the learning process helps create a learning experience that is powerful and rich."

An online leaning community is a destination on the Internet where where the needs of members are addressed through individual-to-individual sharing of knowledge and information (Online learning community, Wikipedia). Such a community is aimed at fostering the learning needs of members by using social networking or computer applications such as texts, audio, or video. The literature does not describe a pre-determined look or feel for an online learning community. However, it is important for members to feel a sense of belonging and that their learning needs are addressed by participation.One common example of a learning community is Community of practice, defined as "a group of people who share a craft and/or a profession" (Community of practice, Wikipedia). Those who form or belong to a community of practice do so to advance their professional objectives by sharing knowledge related to their particular field or profession.

I definitely agree that an online learning environment has certain advantages in creating _opportunities for connection and learning:- In a physical space, there are restrictions on how many people can interact at one time, whereas in an online environment there aren't really physical limitations for how many people can join. - In an online space both public and private conversations can occur (more or less) simultaneously. In an online space, it is possible to pay attention to the main class discussion and connect with class members individually, in the same span of time, whereas in a f2f class it's rude to have side conversations during a discussion! - An online community affords more breadth and depth in a discussion. There's more breadth because everyone gets to write their response, so we get to hear from everyone's unique perspective. As far as depth, in a spoken conversation, there's a "flow", and sometimes things get interrupted, or topics are passed over that could be discussions more deeply. There's more depth with an online conversation board because it's easy to return to past discussions and add more thoughts. Also, when we write text, that makes it much easier to reply exactly to what another person has said. This speaks to what F was saying about an environment that is "challenging". In part, an online discussion is challenging because we have so much more breadth and depth in our discussions to contend with.- Online spaces can be appealing - not always in the same ways as physical spaces, but both can be aesthetically appealing. It's usually easier/less expensive to "remodel" an online space to better suite its members. Often there's more "room" in an online space for members to add their own individuality, like how we can add our personal photos to this group site. I'd like to see us try to do that in a classroom on campus! :-)

Hi All,Please forgive me...I went a little crazy in my post! _I promise to keep it more succinct next time.For a number of years I taught online classes both asynchronously and synchronously. _I was never officially trained or educated how to do it, but got lots of advice from colleagues along the way who had been teaching online. _I stumbled a lot and learned a lot. _Some semesters, my online classes were my favorites, students engaged in ways I had never seen in my face-to-face classes. _Other semesters, to be honest, I just couldn_ wait for it to be over. _Reflecting upon my experiences I know that it had a lot to do with building community. _This was the key reason I wanted to take this class. _How do you build effective online communities?In reading the Palloff and Pratt text, there were a few key items that struck me in terms of building community. _Excuse the long quote, but when I read this I couldn_ help but think this is so dang true!There is one important element, however, that sets online distance learning apart from the traditional classroom setting: Key to the learning process are the interactions among students themselves, the interactions between faculty and students, and the collaboration in learning that results from these interactions. _In other words, the formation of a learning community through which knowledge is imparted and meaning is co-created sets the stage for successful learning outcomes. (Palloff and Pratt, 2007, p. 4) I think about the semesters I loathed my online classes and I know they were the semesters that I was frustrated by my students participation or lack thereof. _I was frustrated that they were not contributing at the level I wanted them to. _So_I became a bit of a tyrant, demanding that they do things in a very specific way. _In a face-to-face class teachers can do that more, we can control the conversations that take place, redirect it in a way we want it to go in a very short amount of time. _It only takes the teacher_ questioning or direct comment and everyone hears it all at once and know to move the conversation that way. _This is not true of online threaded discussions because not everyone is there at that precise moment. _But, that_ also the point. _Like the quote says, there is collaboration in the learning, not a teacher dictating how the learning is to take place. _That's what makes it a unique community!Another item from the text that struck me was that successful students in distance education programs are _able to communicate through writing (Palloff and Pratt, 2007, p. 8). I couldn_ help but think that talkers _win in f-2-f classes, but writers _win in online classes. _But, don_ good writers always win? _That is, ultimately in higher education if you are a strong writer no matter f-2-f or online you will come out on top because after all the major assignments always involve writing. _How can we change that dynamic, even just a little, so that more people can win?Finally, I am intrigued by the difference between presence and interaction as described on page 12. _I think about some stories I have read about how people have become actually lonelier or depressed through social media such as Facebook (FB). _In most of these stories the key was that on FB and other social media people are marketing themselves. _That is, they are posting images of themselves on vacation or some other fantastic place because they want to show the world how great their life is. _It_ almost like marketing a product. _If this is true, then wouldn_ that be considered presence, but not true interaction? _As in, the comments below the wonderful picture, _looks like fun, _you look amazing!, etc.? _It seems to me friends are acknowledging presence not truly interacting. _OK, don_ get me wrong, I am just as guilty of this stuff as anyone_I_ just contemplating this idea. In looking for an article that discusses community I found an interesting one: _Developing Online Learning Communities by Mark. A. Maddix in Christian Education Journal (Series 3, Vol. 10, No.1). _I am neither Christian nor religious, but I found this article intriguing because it deals with the idea of larger community values within an individual classroom community. _In Christian universities one of the elements of their teaching is helping young people in the forming and shaping of their faith. _Classes, therefore, are not just about the content (e.g., history, chemistry), but about modeling Christian values and beliefs. _The concern is that in online classes these values and beliefs may not be modeled. _Moreover, some theologians argue that embodiment is key to molding these beliefs and values and physical presence is necessary. _Maddix presents an alternative viewpoint through various research. _Of particular interest to me is John Gresham_ research that argues for a _divine pedagogy or __the pedagogy of the incarnation [that] points to the realm of the student's life experience as the locus of divine saving action (Maddix, p. 142 and Gresham, 2006, p. 26). _In other words, to use Gresham_ language again, _divine pedagogy includes a communal dimension similar to the church, [it] provides active participation of students in the learning process, and is relevant to online education because it is rich in symbols and signs that communicate meaning (Maddix, p. 142 and Gresham 2006, p. 27-28). _I read such statements as a redefining of community or rather we must not assume that we are a community simply because we share similar values and beliefs. _Rather we must continuously build community and allow the actors to be active, challenged, and provide space for difference and growth. _In other words, we can_ just say our community has these values and beliefs and that you will pick them up simply by your presence. _I like this.In sum, then, an online community really needs to be genuine in its efforts to be a community. _We can't just be together in this space, we need to engage in it.

So, I think of my profession of dental hygiene, living within the ecosystem of organized dentistry. Every-so-often, state Boards of Dentistry make major changes to the individual services that a dental hygienist can legally provide to their patients. Hi R,The difference between a self-evaluation and a team-evaluation is that you are only evaluating yourself in the former. The self-evaluation gives you a chance to reflect on your effort and provides the instructor with an idea of how you feel you performed. On the other hand, a team-evaluation gives all members of the team an opportunity to assess your performance. Often times, team members' ratings are averaged. When this feedback is shared with the instructor, it allows the instructor to gain better insight on how the team worked together. If all of the team members have good things to say about each other, we assume they worked well together. If all the team members identify a single person as a "slacker," this is also noteworthy. One thing that should always be considered, however, is that sometimes team members don't say anything negative because they fear that this may affect their grade or that others may not share the same feelings and they don't want to put an unnecessary light on themselves. I hope this helps answer your question!

What did you find interesting about gamification as described in the article?The part that stuck out to me the most was the fourth paragraph under "How: Goals and Techniques": "It [gamification] gives students clear, actionable tasks and promises them immediate rewards instead of vague long-term benefits...Games maintain this positive relationship with failure by making feedback cycles rapid and keeping the stakes low...in schools, on the other hand, the stakes of failure are high and the feedback cycles long. Is gamification what you thought it was?I have read a little bit about gamification in the past, so Lee and Hammer's description fit with what I thought gamification was. How does gamification differ from actually using games? Gamification is using the techniques of games in a different context. It can mean turning an assignment into a game, but it can also refer to adding a "game component", like a competitive or cooperative element to the assignment. I think there is a lot of nuance around gamification and actually making it work in schools that will have to be discovered by trial and error. Gamification is a lot more than just switching from "grades" to "experience points", leaving everything else the same, and expecting student's motivation to be transformed. It required a much more in depth knowledge of what makes games appealing.I think a lot of the fun of games come from not being mandatory. So that's a hard line to draw in implementing gamification since we want all students to participate and we are accountable for them as teachers. I was thinking about our online learning community and how the book suggested (and Instructor has modeled this) that the community have places both for the required academic discussions/assignments, but also places for more causal, social interaction. Perhaps that is a lesson that could benefit gamification - in a classroom there could be certain games (or parts of a larger game) that are required, but there are also games (or areas of the larger game) that are low-stakes and just for fun. Students can get drawn in to the low-stakes game and work their way up to something more overtly educational.

Because games involve repeated experimentation, they also involve repeated failure. In fact, for many games, the only way to learn how to play the game is to fail at it repeatedly, learning something each time (Gee, 2008). I have chosen complexity under the category - University. _The Welsh scholar Dave Snowden proposed cynefin complexity framework to describe a perspective on the evolutionary nature of complex systems, including their inherent uncertainty. I am interested in complexity system because I think educational system itself is a complexity system.In complexity theory an organism senses and responds to its environment, thereby changing its environment, which changes the organism again, so that the organism reacts to, and thereby _ proactively _ changes, its environment; the process, in iterating itself, produces dynamic and continuous change recursively (Stewart, 1991). _And Educational systems, institutions and practices exhibit many features of complex adaptive systems, being dynamical and emergent, sometimes unpredictable, non-linear organizations operating in unpredictable and changing external environments.The cynefin complexity framework provides a typology of contexts that guides what sort of explanations or solutions might apply. It draws on research into complex adaptive systems theory, cognitive science, anthropology, and narrative patterns, as well as evolutionary psychology, to describe problems, situations, and systems. It "explores the relationship between man, experience, and context"and proposes new approaches to communication, decision-making, policy-making, and knowledge management in complex social environments.Educators can use this framework to evaluate the learning system or learning community. Educators and other stakeholders can use it to do knowledge management, which refers to a multi-disciplined approach to achieving organisational objectives by making the best use of knowledge. It can also be used by software developer to evaluate the quality of products. It align with the key characteristics as followings: it has real-world relevance and provides the opportunity for both instructors and students to making best use of knowledge. Did we create an online learning community?I guess when I began this course, I was thinking of online learning communities more as voluntary sites (like communities of practice) where anyone could go to ask questions, receive a variety of answers/resources from a wide variety of participants of the site; I wasn_ really thinking of them in terms of how we would come to use our Ning course site in this course, as formally enrolled students of an online learning community. But I_e come to see that there are a wide variety of such online learning communities, and we have definitely formed one in this course _ even going so far as to learn together how to work in groups at a distance, both synchronously and asynchronously, and with great success. I have also found myself wanting to share the key aspects of these communities with my colleagues, who are being asked to develop online learning opportunities for the courses they teach F2F _ particularly, the need to develop that social presence, to engage learners effectively (many are thinking only in terms of loading content online, in the beginning). So, I would have to say that my conceptions of online learning have shifted considerably, due to my involvement in this course. Six Essential Elements: honesty, responsiveness, relevance, respect, openness, empowerment. Where did this class succeed? Fall short? I feel that as an instructor, Instructor very effectively modeled how we should incorporate these essential elements into this community: by conveying her thoughts and challenges as an instructor very honestly (for example, her reaction to the vaccination precluding her from capturing herself in the video of our final week_ assignment); we were encouraged to participate through being responsive to those in the class with us, by contributing unique & relevant content to the discussions (learning in groups produces far more knowledge than learning solo); the class charter reinforced these ideals, as well as that of responding respectfully to our classmates contributions. We were asked to be open, and did so, I would say. And as the instructor, Instructor empowered us to explore beyond the content covered in the syllabus, to complete assignments on our own schedule, as adult learners with competing life demands, yet giving us time _goals in which to complete things. All of these elements were encouraged in this class, at a level appropriate to us as adult learners, I feel. As far as falling short, I may_e missed the timelines on a few of the goal dates for completion, but I don_ feel the course itself fell short in any areas. These online distance learning courses, to me, actually _set the bar for this type of instruction. And they have helped me immeasurably in the work that I do.In what ways (if any) did the establishment of a class charter shape your experiences?I feel that a community charter is essential, to outline for members what is expected from them, as far as contributions to the group, and also what they can expect from other members. As I plan to develop such an online community of practice in the near future, I can see that a charter will be essential to the process, especially as it clearly defines member expectations and gives me something to refer to, if I need to ask someone to leave the community for poor behavior, etc.Identify 2 _take aways from the course. In this way, online teaching is more demanding than F2F (though perhaps more rewarding, too). A second take-away is the importance of authenticity and building of the social presence in online communities because, without this, no trust is built and the interactions become more guarded, and may likely diminish rather than flourish.Identify suggestions for future CI 5323 courses.Just a comment, I guess: I felt that the workload for this course was more manageable, somehow, than that for CI5325; perhaps this was because I had far more work/personal demands last semester; but it seemed that in CI5325 there were many more hours needed to complete assignments.
